sentences: The bus is stopping at the corner.
He stops when the light turns red.
Yesterday, she stopped at the store.

prompts.stem: Build a matrix for this base. Select words that keep the base spelling stable, then prove one with a word sum, a join note, and a spelling rebuild.

questions.text: In the sentence context, what does <stopping> mean?
What is the base that carries the core meaning across the matrix words?
Use the matrix to generate related words that keep the base spelling stable. Select at least four.
Choose one selected word and write a word sum that resembles it. Include a join note.
Now spell the whole word using your word sum + join note.

supports.content: The base in this word family is <stop> because it carries the core meaning across related words.
Join note: The spelling changes by ________ because ________.
Spelling rebuild: I start with <stop>, then I ________ (join step), then I add <****> to spell <********>.

response.spelling_rebuild_prompt: Type the final spelled word you built from your word sum and join note.

rubric.criterion: Selects multiple matrix-buildable words that preserve the base spelling
Produces a word sum proof that resembles the chosen word
Includes a join note supported by letter evidence
Correctly spells the whole word from the word sum + join note

metadata.notes_for_teacher: This task highlights the doubling convention for CVC bases before vowel suffixes (<-ing>, <-ed>). Students should notice that the base spelling <stop> stays stable, and the final consonant doubles at the join. Students then rebuild the final spelling from their word sum + join note.
